name: NPR
text:
Florida has issued a directive requiring all school districts to offer in-person instruction. 

But as COVID-19 cases surge in the state, many educators are questioning the push to reopen schools next month. https://t.co/1lXXu4QFOA

name: NPR
text:
Indonesia now has more than 80,000 confirmed coronavirus cases, with more than 3,200 dead. Epidemiologists say it's due to government failures, including misinformation.

"I don't think Indonesia has the means to stop the disease now," one scientist says.
https://t.co/ZPAED77O95

name: NPR
text:
The NSA says Russian hackers are attempting to break into organizations working on a potential coronavirus vaccine. The agency believes they're part of the group blamed for hacking Democratic Party emails in 2016.
 https://t.co/ifUFQHMxgJ

name: NPR
text:
The Republican party has announced it will scale back its August convention in Florida.

Attendance for the first few days will be limited to RNC delegates, which is a little more than 2,500 people. The final day is expected to total about 7,000. https://t.co/9XPvSwlwii

name: NPR
text:
The Asheville City Council has approved a reparations resolution for Black residents and formally apologized for the local government's historic role in slavery and racist and discriminatory policies.
https://t.co/C2hFNAycTe

name: NPR
text:
In 2013, the GOP produced a report laying out how the party should move forward — including expanding outreach to people of color, women and young voters.

Today, it's a window into the pressures that some fear will hurt the party for generations to come.
https://t.co/jRvwI6HecK

name: NPR
text:
Capt. Tom Moore will soon become Capt. Sir Tom Moore.

The 100-year-old WWII veteran will be knighted by Queen Elizabeth II on Friday after he raised more than $40 million for health care workers by walking laps in his garden.
https://t.co/rWN0JAq1aH

name: NPR
text:
The mayor of New Bedford, Mass., issued emergency orders with a set of enforceable guidelines to protect essential workers during the pandemic. Safety experts say it could be a model for cities across the country.
https://t.co/hIIA9QTlVH

name: NPR
text:
India has set a new record for its daily coronavirus cases, reporting 32,695 new infections on Thursday. The country's numbers continue to soar — exceeded only by the United States and Brazil.
https://t.co/tOMHip0Md9

name: NPR
text:
In May, President Trump vetoed a bipartisan bill promoting debt forgiveness for veterans who were defrauded by for-profit schools.

Now, the Department of Veterans Affairs is allowing several repeat-offending schools access to GI Bill money.
 https://t.co/tJqz1nv9oa

name: NPR
text:
Supermarkets and gas stations across the U.S. are grappling with the pandemic-induced coin shortage.

To combat the low supply, some are loading change onto loyalty cards — while others are rounding up amounts to donate to charity.
https://t.co/rxZCYXBTbZ

name: NPR
text: RT @m_scribe: Rwandans know what it is like to lose hundreds of thousands of relatives and friends in just a few months. Here's how they are recovering: by remembering the dead and vowing "never again." My latest for @nprworld   https://t.co/kMxUTLgmr2

name: NPR
text:
The Met will reopen to the public in late August. Officials said "comprehensive" new health and safety procedures will be put in place — including requiring masks and limiting the number of visitors.
https://t.co/BMjYWCJ6u0

name: NPR
text:
Author Joanna Cole, whose Magic School Bus series made science both dazzling and fun for generations of children, died over the weekend at age 75. The beloved TV show aired for 18 years.
https://t.co/YKmQzYuQnw

name: NPR
text:
Electronic musicians from Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean sampled the sounds of endangered birds from their countries for a new album — and its proceeds go directly toward efforts to save them.
https://t.co/HaHDFJxM5v

name: NPR
text:
A new step-by-step manual from the Vatican that details how to investigate and report sexual abuse cases involving clergy calls on church authorities to alert civil officials even if not required to do so by law.
https://t.co/qaWe1QKbkq

name: NPR
text:
Americans are on pace to buy more guns than ever amid the pandemic. And nearly half of all the sales appear to be to first-time gun owners.

One economist's analysis says racial tensions are driving at least some of the surge in sales.
https://t.co/wsZfdSpRDS
